intro: Haplopappus havardii, commonly known as the Havard's pappus, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and robust, hairy stems. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, thriving in well-drained soils. Its small, yellowish flowers are followed by fluffy, white pappus structures that aid in wind dispersal of its seeds. Haplopappus havardii is often found in rocky or sandy habitats, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions.
